storyTypes.name: News Conference
storyTypes.description: Reporting on press conferences and official announcements.

questions.text: What were the major points made in the announcement of the press conference?
What are the names and job titles or official positions of speakers?
What is the background of major points of the conference?
What further info came out of the question and answer session?
What questions were not answered or avoided?
Make sure you get copies of any handouts from the press conference.
What are the contact details of the organisers (preferably phone numbers) in case of queries?

storyTypes.name: Speech
storyTypes.description: Reporting on speeches and public addresses.

questions.text: What was the speaker's main point?
What is the name and title of the main speaker? (Make sure name is spelt correctly!)
What quotes do you have to support main point?
What was the purpose, time and location of the speech?
How many people attended and what was their makeup and reactions?
Did the speaker make any additional points?
What is the background to the major point they made?
What comments did the speaker make before and after their speech?
Is there any additional info from the question and answer period?
Do you have copies of speeches and/or background documents?
What are the contact details (preferably phone numbers/business cards) of speakers in case of queries?

storyTypes.name: Protest March
storyTypes.description: Reporting on protests, marches, strikes and demonstrations.

questions.text: Ensure you have a large scarf and a bottle of vinegar (soak scarf in vinegar if police use teargas) in case there is teargas.
What kind of protest is it? A march, a strike, a barricade?
Who are the main organisers of the protest? Get their official title, organisation and contact details.
Was the protest planned or unplanned?
What is the reason for the protest?
Were any NGOs or political parties involved or related to the protest? Get their names, organisation, contact details and reason for involvement.
What is the size of the crowd: don't guess! Check with organisers and police.
Get a quote from the organisers about the protest.
Interview a minimum of 10 protesters: get their name, age, where they live, why they are protesting, what do they want to achieve?
Have there been any related protests in the past (how many, when and where) and was anything achieved?
How did the authorities and police respond to the protest?
Did police use any non-lethal force (teargas, rubber bullets) or lethal force (live ammunition), or both?
Was anyone injured? Who, how many and how badly?
To which hospitals/clinics were the injured taken for treatment?
If there are reports of violent force from police, do you have evidence and do you have a response from the police about this?
What is the current status of the protest?

storyTypes.name: Motor Accidents
storyTypes.description: Reporting on vehicle accidents and road incidents.

questions.text: What time did the accident happen and where?
Were any people injured or dead and how many?
What type of vehicles were involved?
What is the identification of the drivers involved? Names, ages, addresses, other personal information.
What was the cause of the accident? (according to paramedics, police or other official sources)
What is the identification of any others involved? (Passengers, pedestrians.)
What is the identification of the injured and dead?
What is the extent of any injuries?
What is the condition of the injured?
Where were the injured and dead taken? (Which hospital or morgue?)
Were there any acts of bravery or any rescues?
Were there any arrests or other legal action?
What is the damage to the vehicles?
What was the speed of vehicles involved?
Where were they coming from/going to?
Were there any strange weather or road conditions that could have caused the accident?
What happened according to eyewitnesses, investigating officers and people involved in incident?
What are the funeral arrangements for the dead?

storyTypes.name: Health Services
storyTypes.description: Reporting on service delivery issues at clinics or hospitals.

questions.text: What is the name of the hospital or clinic and where is it situated?
What services are not being offered when they should be? (areas of lack of service delivery)
Why are these services no longer being offered?
Who is affected by this? (A particular group of people / area and what are their socio-economic backgrounds?)
How many people are affected, at risk or in danger because of the withdrawal of these services?
What are the names and ages of those affected and what are their experiences?
How long do patients wait to be seen by doctors/health workers?
Is there sufficient - and the correct - medication available?
Who is responsible for delivering the services?
What is the response from officials responsible for delivering the service?
Have patients visited the facility previously? If yes, was their file available when they were treated?
What distance did patients you interviewed have to travel to get there?
How did they get there? (bus, taxi, train, walk)
What was the cost of their return fare?

storyTypes.name: Specific Illness
storyTypes.description: Reporting on specific diseases or health conditions.

questions.text: What is the name of the sickness/condition that the patient has?
What are the main symptoms?
What treatment did they receive?
Where are they being treated?
Is the illness contagious and have there been any other reports of it locally or abroad?
What is the identification of victims? Names, ages, addresses, other personal information.
What comments, if any, did health workers make on the sickness?
What distance did patients you interviewed have to travel to get there and what is the cost of their return fares?

storyTypes.name: Courts - Civil Action
storyTypes.description: Reporting on civil court cases and lawsuits.

questions.text: Who is the person or organisation filing the action? Names, ages, addresses, other personal information.
What is the background of the plaintiff or petitioner: the person filing the action?
What is the background of the defendant or respondent?
What type of damage is alleged?
What is the outcome being sought?
What is the date of filing of the application and which is the court of jurisdiction?
Is there a special motivation behind the action (if any)?
What is the background to the conflict/disagreement?
Are there or have there been any similar cases decided by courts (precedents)?
Could this suit lead to a landmark action? Is it a precedent?
Is there a possibility of an out-of-court settlement?
What is the significance of the action and the effect on others?
What are the names of the lawyers for both sides? (Check spelling!)
What is the date and who is the presiding judge for the trial or hearing?

storyTypes.name: Courts - Verdict
storyTypes.description: Reporting on court verdicts and judgments.

questions.text: What is the verdict and damages, if awarded? (Same, less, greater than the damages sought?)
Who are the parties involved?
Did the judge make a statement? Did it deviate from assessor's findings?
Give a summary of the allegations by plaintiff.
What was the key testimony and attorney/advocate's main points?
For how long did the court deliberate before judgement?
Are there any appeals or motions?

storyTypes.name: Crime
storyTypes.description: Reporting on criminal incidents and investigations.

questions.text: What is the name and details of the victims? Names, ages, addresses, other personal information.
What was the crime and how was it committed?
What is the date, time and location of the crime? Confirm with official sources.
In the case of death, what was the official cause? (According to paramedics, police or other official sources.)
What injuries did the victims suffer and what weapon was used?
What was the motivation for the crime and what is the background of victim? (if relevant?)
Have there been any arrests and are there any suspects or clues?
Are there any strange circumstances surrounding the crime?
Get comment from the victim, witnesses, police and other official sources.

storyTypes.name: Fires
storyTypes.description: Reporting on fires and related emergencies.

questions.text: How many people are dead and injured?
What is the identification of victims? Names, ages, addresses, other personal information.
Where was the fire and what was burning (a building, house, field, etc.)?
When did the fire start, where and how did it spread?
When and after how long was it brought under control?
How were victims killed and injured and what is the extent of the injuries?
Property loss: what is the extent, cost of damage, insurance? You may need to phone an expert.
Investigation: any unusual circumstances?
Where were the injured and dead taken? (Which hospital or morgue?)
Were there any acts of bravery or any rescues?
Get comments from neighbours, eyewitnesses.
How many fire engines and firefighters involved?
Sources: Fire chief, police, rescue services, hospital, mortuary, welfare agencies

storyTypes.name: Sports
storyTypes.description: Reporting on sporting events and matches.

questions.text: What type of sport are you reporting on?
What is the name of the teams playing?
What was the final score?
Where and when did game take place?
What was the key play, strategy; turning point of game?
Who were the outstanding players?
What effect does the result have on standings, rankings, individual records?
What was the scoring pattern of the game?
Are there any winning/losing streaks, records involved by team, player?
Get comments from coaches, players and fans of both teams.
What was the crowd size and how was their behaviour?
Were there any injuries?
How long was the game and did they run into extra time?
What are the game's statistics?

storyTypes.name: Biography
storyTypes.description: Writing a biographical profile of a person.

questions.text: What is the full name of the person you're writing about?
What is their age and date of birth?
What is their place of birth and where did they live?
What is their physical description? (This is important to add colour to your piece.)
Details of their character and personality? (Ask family and friends.)
Details of their education? (Include any degrees earned.)
Details of personal relationships with family, friends, work colleagues.
Details of awards / honours / formal recognition.
Summarise any of their major contributions to society and the world.
List at least THREE major political or social events which occurred during this person's life. For each event, explain how it may have affected your biographical subject.

storyTypes.name: Obituaries
storyTypes.description: Writing an obituary for a deceased person.

questions.text: What is the name, age, address, occupation of the deceased?
What was the time, place and cause of death?
What is the person's birthdate, birthplace?
Who are they survived by? (immediate family)
What are the funeral and burial arrangements?
What are the deceased's accomplishments?
What are the details of their education?
Were they members of any clubs or societies, such as a stokvel, Rotary or Lions?
Did they do military service? (formal or otherwise)
Anecdotes, recollections of friends, relatives?

storyTypes.name: General Story
storyTypes.description: A flexible template for any type of story.

questions.text: What type of story is it: news report, feature, investigation, editorial?
What topic are you writing about?
What is the identification of the people involved? Names, ages, addresses, other personal information.
How many sources do you need to speak to?
What kind of experts do you need to speak to and how many?
What kind of background research do you need to do?

storyTypes.name: Budget Adoption
storyTypes.description: Reporting on government budget announcements and fiscal policy.

questions.text: What is the amount to be spent?
Are there new or increased taxes, higher licence and permit fees, and other income that will be necessary to meet expenditure?
Are there any cuts in taxes, fees or fines?
How does this compare to previous years?
What is the justification for increases sought, or cuts made?
What is the rate of current spending and is it under or over the previous year's budget?
Are there patterns behind the submission and subsequent adjustments, like political motives, pressure groups, historical factors?
What are the consequences of this budget for: agencies, departments, businesses, the public?

storyTypes.name: Meetings
storyTypes.description: Reporting on official meetings, councils, and assemblies.

questions.text: What is the agenda for next meeting?
Major actions: what are the details of votes, decisions, agreements, resolutions?
Vote: what are the names/positions for those who voted for and against motions?
What are the reasons for actions?
What was the purpose, time and location of meeting?
What discussions and debates took place and how long did the meeting last?
Quotes from witnesses, experts, attendees.
What was the audience's makeup? (who was there?)
Agenda; were any last minute items added, any departures from agenda?
Are there potential consequences of actions/decisions taken at meeting?

storyTypes.name: Disasters
storyTypes.description: Reporting on natural disasters and major emergencies.

questions.text: What are the details of dead, causes of death and mortuaries bodies dead were taken to?
Injured: what is the extent of their injuries?
How many people are affected or in danger?
What hospitals/clinics were the injured taken to?
What is the estimated death and injury toll?
Seek eyewitness and survivor accounts.
Property loss and damage: what is the damage to homes, land, public utilities, permanent damage.
Information about rescue and relief operations? Were there any evacuations, acts of heroism, unusual equipment used or unique rescue techniques?
Have the authorities issued any warnings or statements? (Health department, public utility, police statements)
Has there been any looting?
Are the police/army/security forces visible on the ground?
Is there insurance for damage? (Public and private properties)
Are there many spectators?
Have there been any arrests?
Has an official investigation been launched? If so, by whom?

storyTypes.name: Profile
storyTypes.description: Writing a profile piece about a person.

questions.text: What is the name, identification, other details of subject? (get correct spelling)
What is their background? (birth, upbringing, education, jobs)
What is the theme of your profile?
Why are you writing this profile? (news value)
Anecdotes and incidents (from subject, friends, associates)?
Use physical descriptions (do NOT use adjectives like "attractive")
Make observations of subject at work, play, home; mannerisms, gestures.
Make sure you get lots of quotes from the people you interview.
